portfolioItems.title: Island game
portfolioItems.description:
Island Game - Full Stack Project Overview

Introduction
The Island Game is an interactive full-stack application that challenges players to find the island with the highest average height on a grid map. It seamlessly integrates a Java Spring Boot backend with an Angular frontend to provide an engaging user experience.

Project Overview
Players are presented with a 30x30 grid map consisting of water and land cells, each assigned specific height values. Connected land cells form islands, and the objective is to identify the island with the highest average height within three attempts.

Backend Details
    Data Retrieval and Parsing: Fetches raw map data from an external API endpoint and processes it to distinguish between water cells (height 0) and land cells (height > 0).
    Island Identification: Groups connected land cells into distinct islands and calculates the average height for each island.
    REST API: Provides structured and processed data to the frontend for visualization and gameplay.

Tech Stack
    Java Spring Boot: Handles API requests, data parsing, and core backend logic.
    RESTful API: Enables communication between the backend and frontend.
    Docker: Facilitates deployment alongside the frontend using a docker-compose.yml file.

Frontend Details
    Interactive Grid Map: Displays a dynamic grid where players can visualize water and land cells.
    User Interaction: Allows players to click on cells to select and highlight islands.
    Game Mechanics: Tracks player guesses, provides feedback, and manages game state (win, lose, restart).

Tech Stack
    Angular: Manages the dynamic user interface, user interactions, and game logic.
    REST API Calls: Communicates with the backend to fetch map data and submit guesses.
    Docker: Ensures easy deployment alongside the backend.

portfolioItems.title: Financial web application
portfolioItems.description:
This application simulates a stock trading platform designed for use by agents in a banking environment. It retrieves the latest data on stocks, futures, forex, and other financial instruments from online databases, allowing multiple users to engage in simultaneous trading activities. Agents can seamlessly buy and sell investments, providing a realistic trading experience.
Additionally, the app features components that simulate banking accounts for regular customers, as well as a rudimentary mobile app to facilitate card purchases and provide access to user accounts.
The infrastructure is built using a microservices architecture, enabling efficient communication between services via HTTP methods. The application is divided into distinct components that manage user accounts, agent actions, specialized purchases, and client interactions.
To ensure scalability and ease of deployment, the entire application has been containerized using Docker and is orchestrated on a Kubernetes cluster.

portfolioItems.title: Vimeo Video Demo App
portfolioItems.description:
This is a demo app that collects videos (currently set to music) from the Vimeo API and displays them in a RecyclerView. The app consists of two parts:
 Regular XML App: A traditional Android app using XML-based UI.
    Compose App: An Android app using Jetpack Compose for UI.

Functionality

The app provides the following functionalities:
    Automatic Loading: The app automatically loads 20 videos on the first launch.
    Lazy Loading: Additional videos are loaded when the user scrolls to the bottom of the list.
    Detailed View: Clicking on a video opens a detailed description of it and simultaneously opens a player.
    Two App Versions: The app has both traditional XML-based UI and Jetpack Compose-based UI.

Swapping Between Apps
To swap between the two versions of the app, press the floating action button.

portfolioItems.title: K-Means Clustering
portfolioItems.description:
This Java project utilizes the K-means clustering algorithm to find the optimal placement of processing plants across Europe. The primary objective is to minimize the distance between waste accumulation sites (garbage collection facilities) and processing plants, enhancing the efficiency of waste management.

Context
In Europe, various locations serve as garbage collection facilities, each with a specific annual capacity measured in tonnes. This capacity represents the amount of waste accumulated annually at each site. The project aims to determine the sub-optimal placement of a given number of processing plants to efficiently process this accumulated waste.

K-Means Clustering
K-means clustering is a fundamental algorithm in the field of clustering. It segregates a given dataset into a specified number (k) of clusters, optimizing the intra-cluster variance. In this project, the algorithm is tailored to handle GPS coordinates of locations in Europe, clustering them based on their proximity and capacity for waste accumulation.
